popups.text: Welcome to The Pyramid Puzzles!

This is a game based on 'The Chinese Room Argument'. It's a philosophical thought experiment by John Searle that aims to see if modern computers can ever 'understand' the things they've been programmed to do.

You're a new intern in the Heiroglyph Translation Department in the University of New South Wale's Egyptology deparment. You've been sent to Egypt to help translate these ancient messages! You will receive a message written in Heiroglyphs from the outside, and your job is to use the dictionary and rulebook provided to create the right response, and send that back outside. Make sense?
Let me show you the ropes. Follow along with the directions I give you.
Firstly, you receive a message from the outside. Look, one's just come in below! Try dragging it around.
Then, you can open your rulebook to find out how to respond. You can drag the popup around as needed. After the tutorial, if you want to close it, just click the book again.
To make your response, firstly, click the dictionary below to access your available characters. You can drag the popout dictionary around too!
Using the rule stated in the rulebook, drag the characters from the dictionary onto the paper in the right order.
Amazing, now that your answer is ready, click the top right corner of the paper to complete it.

buttons.text: I've made the new piece of paper.

popups.text: Great! Now both of those paper slips are ready to combine. Click on the stapler to open it.
Fantastic, now you can drag both the request and your response onto the stapler menu, and a button will appear which you can use to staple them together!
Now, the final step is to drag your completed order to the right side, a menu will appear where you can either bin it or finish the job.

And that's all you'll need to know for your first day on the job! Keep a look out on the top left to keep track of how you're progressing, we'll be explaining the meaning of all this labour soon. Good luck!

popups.text: Congratulations, you're doing an excellent job so far! Just one question for you, do you feel like doing this is teaching you to understand Heiroglyphs?
Really? So if someone texted you using Heiroglyphs right now, with one of the rules in that rulebook, could you intelligently respond?

I'm going to have to disagree with you there, I'll explain why. And just before I get into the finer details, I want to note that a question mark will appear in the top right hand corner of this dialogue box for more complicated stages. This calls our purpose-built AI teacher to assist in your understanding!

You are right there. But let's explore why. And just before I get into the finer details, I want to note that a question mark will appear in the top right hand corner of this dialogue box for more complicated stages. This calls our purpose-built AI teacher to assist in your understanding!

'Understanding' can mean two things. Firstly, 'Syntax', which is putting words in a correct order. Secondly, 'Semantics', which is what the words mean. When you follow the rulebook, which type of 'understanding' are you using?

That's right! Your rulebook is telling you exactly how to construct an output given an input, but there's nothing there that teaches you why a given output should occur from those inputs. Or is there? Do you think with enough time and enough rules you would be able to fully understand Heiroglyphics?

Not quite, that would mean you understand the meaning behind all the characters your placing. But in your case you understand how to place them in the correct order, the syntax, but there's nothing there that teaches you 'why' you should be placing them in that order, the semantics. Or is there? Do you think with enough time and enough rules you would be able to fully understand Heiroglyphics?

Well that's the interesting thing. Because from the outside you would appear to understand Heiroglpyhs. Given enough rules, anyone who knew how to read and write them can ask you any question they want, and you could to respond with the right thing. Whether Geography, History, or Math, they could ask you a question and you could respond. But, you would never be able to know what your saying.

buttons.text: I see, what does this all mean

popups.text: If you hadn't realised yet, in this situation, you are the brain of a computer, the 'CPU' - Central Processing Unit. You are (1) given a request (user input), (2) use your instructions to make your response (program code), and (3) put it in the responses pile (output). But I think I've done enough talking, how about I add some more rules and see if you can imagine how you might be a computer and we'll discuss more soon.
So, how was that, do you understand Heiroglyphics any better now?

If you are confident that you can make the jump from syntax to semantics, you may be a proponent of so-called 'strong AI', that in a matter of time our computers are going to achieve 'AGI' - Artificial General Intelligence. But let me tell you why you should be at least a bit skeptical of that.

Right, as discussed you cannot make the jump from syntax to semantics. This has implications for the theory of 'strong AI', that in a matter of time our computers are going to achieve 'AGI' - Artificial General Intelligence. Let me try and explain why this may be unlikely to be the case.

As I mentioned previously, like you right now, computers are just highly complicated symbol manipulation machines. At the most basic level, they are given a series of inputs, represented as either 1 or 0. Then, based on the program it's been given, it creates a new series of 1's and 0's to send back out. At a high level, this process may be interpreted by us as music, video, colour, or any number of other meaningful things. But to the computer, it's just moving around 1's and 0's, exactly the same way as you in the Heiroglyphics room, you're just moving around characters.

buttons.text: But can't the system learn the meaning?

popups.text: A computer can never 'learn' in the way that we think of learning, because it's entirely limited to syntax. A computer never knows why it manipulates the symbols (1's and 0's) its given in different ways. Even if to us it seems to 'correctly' interpret our input, that's only because we told it how. However, I will admit, this argument is based on programs that are pre-defined. I've given you rules that provide an exact answer every time, but that's not how modern AI LLM's - 'Large Language Models' work.

Instead of telling you, I think I'll show you. Now, for every rule you won't just be following direct programming, you're going to be randomly generating the response on the fly. Go check out the rule book and you'll see what I mean, good luck!
Okay, so how was that, do you think what you were responding with made any sense?
Precisely right, each generation was just a random series of Heiroglyphs. But I promise that there is a connection here to AI.
Not exactly, all the options you generated were actually a completely random series of characters. But I promise that there is a connection here to AI.

You can think of this as the initial training state for an LLM, here we are aiming to develop a 'probabilistic' model. AI chatbots like ChatGPT or Google Gemini start off knowing nothing. If you tried to ask it a question at this stage it would just randomly guess words. If asked ‚Äúwhat colour is a tree?‚Äù it may have responded ‚Äúballoon giant the frog‚Äù, who knows. The same is the case for the letters you just made, the syntax and semantics would be completely wrong.

buttons.text: So how do we make it make sense

popups.text: That's where feedback comes in. You can let it know when it's made a mistake, and let it try again. Then when you next generate a random response, it's like will tweaking odds on the spinwheel to see if it gets closer or further to the answer you were expecting when asked the same question again. And it will probably get it wrong for hundreds, even thousands of attempts. But, eventually, it will say something like ‚Äúthe colour is brown‚Äù and the spinwheel odds will become much more biased towards that output, making it 1 in a billion that it would say something like ‚Äúballoon giant the frog‚Äù. But, even once training is complete, every time an LLM answers your question it is still just continually making good guesses as to what the right words would be.

buttons.text: But why go through this extra effort

popups.text: This is what allows LLM models to be dynamic and evolving. If you need a human to handcraft every response to every possible question it will take quite literally forever. To a 'hard-coded' machine the similarity between ‚Äúwhat colour is a tree?‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat colour are trees?‚Äù is none. They both need a separate encoding, as they use a different final character. Like you wouldn't realise if it turned out ìÄÄìÉπìÉí and ìÄÄìÉπìÜ§ translated to the above. However, to an LLM, these things can be interpreted as similar.

That's the scary thing, we don't know. They do so through Neural Networks, which aim to mimic the brain, but the methods that they come up with to create their answers are incomprehensible to scientists. However, what we do know is that at the most fundamental level they are still dealing with the same 1's and 0's that the computer running the hard-coded program is dealing with. For all their power, they cannot escape their hardware. The same as humans are constrained to their biology. You, in the Heiroglyphics Room, cannot think yourself into understanding these symbols, the same as the computer cannot ‚Äúthink‚Äù itself into understanding the meaning behind its flipping of 1's and 0's.

buttons.text: So where does that leave us

popups.text: This leaves us with the notion that AI as we know it likely won't become 'conscious'. It doesn't discount the idea of new forms of intelligence forming, but just that computers as we've built them today are constrained in this way. But this doesn't discount the importance that emerging AI systems will have in changing the way we live, work, and learn. Just that, maybe, we should be careful how much we trust a system that literally doesn't know what it is talking about. That's the end for now, thanks for playing!
